Introduction/Harmonising-the-variants.title: Harmonising the variants
Introduction/Harmonising-the-variants.description: Each variant is harmonised by aligning it with a reference datasetâ€”specifically, the Ensembl VCF reference. This process ensures allele consistency and corrects the orientation of alleles to match the forward strand. Proper harmonization is critical for ensuring that all variants are aligned correctly and ready for downstream analysis.

Introduction/Orientation-of-palindromic-.title: Orientation of palindromic variants
Introduction/Orientation-of-palindromic-.description: Palindromic variants are genetic variants (such as A/T or G/C SNPs) that appear identical on both the forward and reverse DNA strands, making it difficult to distinguish their true orientation. To ensure that these variants are correctly aligned during harmonisation, the pipeline employs a method to infer their strand orientation using a strand consensus approach.

Limitations.description: While our tools are designed to deliver robust and efficient solutions for harmonizing summary statistic data, it is important for users to understand certain limitations to make informed decisions when utilizing the harmonized results.

Tutorials/Preparing-Reference-Files.title: Preparing Reference Files
Tutorials/Preparing-Reference-Files.description: A reference file is a dataset that contains detailed information about known genetic variants, including at least their genomic positions, reference alleles, and alternative alleles. These reference files are crucial for variant harmonisation, as they determine both whether and how your variants will be harmonised.

Tutorials/Preparing-the-Executor.title: Preparing the Executor
Tutorials/Preparing-the-Executor.description: Nextflow supports running pipelines on a variety of execution environments, including local machines, HPC systems, and cloud platforms. The default executor for this pipeline is SLURM, but you can easily switch between different environments by modifying the executor settings in the executor.config file.
